On 17 June 2015 at 14:52, Jeff Lowe jlowe@... [rest-discuss] <
r=
est-discuss-noreply@yahoogroups.com> wrote:


> I struggled with this for a=
 while for a particular use case. My API needed
> to support the releasing =
of a customer-order to manufacturing. That
> suggested the URL ../orders/{i=
d}/release.
>
>
>
> However I was entertaining that =E2=80=9Cverbs are RPC =
and resources are REST=E2=80=9D,
> and =E2=80=9Crelease=E2=80=9D is obvious=
ly a verb. I entertained a few different approaches:
>
> 1.      PUT an ord=
er resource and set the =E2=80=9Cstate=E2=80=9D to released. That
> didn=E2=
=80=99t seem right because =E2=80=9Crelease=E2=80=9D is more of a business =
process than a
> property on a resource. In addition I=E2=80=99d be exposin=
g internal state that
> shouldn=E2=80=99t necessarily be exposed.
>

This i=
s the correct way to do it. Any change of state is a 'process' even
if all =
it takes is flipping a bit in a database.
REST asks that you provide the *d=
esired state* of a resource (URL) and the
server is responsible for transit=
ioning from whatever state it is in
currently to the desired state.

For ex=
ample a simple issue in an issue-tracker has a field with four
values: repo=
rted, open, and closed. The verbs "accept" and "re-open" would
both be used=
 in natural language to describe the transitions to "open" from
the other t=
wo states, but a RESTful API would only allow the user to state
the end val=
ue for the field, "open", and it would be up to the server to
transition fr=
om either reported or closed as appropriate (or do nothing if
it was alread=
y open).


> 2.      POST to an order-releaser resource. That=E2=80=99s mor=
e restful, but
> seems artificial.
>

This is not RESTful, it's RPC.

-- 
N=
icholas.
